sections.heading: Overview
content: Ed Ergenzinger, a patent attorney who also holds a PhD in neuroscience, was diagnosed with bipolar I at the beginning of 2019 after several life challenges triggered a severe cycle of mania. Severe depression followed, leaving him unemployed, bankrupt, and collecting Social Security Disability. With the help of medication and therapy, he returned to practicing patent law in 2021. His experiences led him to create a course he also teaches – Mental Health and the Legal Profession – at Wake Forest University School of Law. He and his wife, Meredith, live in Raleigh, North Carolina.
Changes in one or more of the five primary senses during a manic or hypomanic episode seems to be common among those of us with bipolar disorder.
Like many people with bipolar disorder, I was in denial about my condition for a long time.
